column1: #Text=Wikinews interviews former Republican U.S. Senator Bob Smith on his latest run for office
#Text=Earlier this month , former Republican U.S. Senator Bob Smith announced his candidacy for Florida 's open Senate seat in the 2010 midterm election .

#Text=Smith , who was one of New Hampshire 's senators for two terms — which amounts to twelve years — said he is running for office in his recently adopted home state due to his disapproval of the direction in which America is headed .
#Text=He is very optimistic about the conservative change he can potentially bring to Congress which is currently controlled by liberal -minded members of the Democratic Party .
#Text=Smith has , however , some major hurdles to overcome in the Republican primary .
#Text=He is facing two well known politicians who have been elected to statewide office numerous times .
#Text=The chief of these is current Governor Charlie Crist , a moderate-to-liberal who is currently leading in the polls .

#Text=The second is former Speaker of the Florida House Marco Rubio , a center-right 38-year-old who has been criticizing Crist for months on the support he has shown for President Barack Obama 's controversial economic stimulus package .
#Text=Despite trailing both in recent polls , Smith believes that the polls themselves are irrelevant as the primary is over one year away .
#Text=He is devoting the remainder of this summer to building up grassroots and financial support for his campaign .
#Text=Wikinews reporter Joseph Ford had the opportunity to speak with him about his run this past weekend .
#Text=" We must deliver a message that appeals to all members of the Republican Party , and that will appeal to Floridians in the general election , " Smith proclaimed .
#Text=" I am in this race because I want to make my experience as a U.S. Senator available to my fellow Floridians .
